key_points: The next frontier is Exascale computing.
Achieving theoretical peak performance is challenging.
Hardware complexity impacts performance.
Heterogeneity, memory hierarchy, and interconnect are key complexities.

Exascale computing represents a significant step in processing speed.
The gap between theoretical and sustained performance is growing.
Heterogeneity, memory hierarchy, and interconnect are key challenges in Exascale systems.
Optimization techniques are crucial for solving large-scale problems, including those in AI.
Efficient implementation of mathematical programming and combinatorial methods on supercomputers is difficult.
Combinatorial problems are major computing challenges.
Large-scale scenarios are becoming more common.
Optimization, combinatorial, and numerical approaches are key to solving these problems.
Traditional methods (e.g., simplex) can outperform newer methods (e.g., ellipsoid) in practice.
Implementation efforts focus on mapping existing methods onto specific computing systems.
A complete optimization solution often involves multiple components.
Operations research is the science of decision making, using mathematical models.
Increasing market size and complexity necessitate optimal decisions for companies.
Mathematical programming is a strong formalism for solving major problems.
Common combinatorial problems can be formulated as minimizing a function subject to constraints.
Linear programming (LP), integer linear programming (ILP), and mixed integer programming (MIP) are important classes of optimization problems.
The Knapsack Problem and the Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP) are illustrative examples.
Supercomputer capability boosts enthusiasm for solving large-scale problems.
Branch-and-cut and branch-and-price are well-studied variants of branch-and-bound.
Linear programming is a key ingredient connecting discrete and continuous optimization.
Parallel computing is crucial for tackling intractable combinatorial problems.
Challenges include managing shared variables, numerical sensitivity, and data exchanges on supercomputers.
Optimization combines applied mathematics and technical computing.
The increasing power of supercomputers drives the desire to solve large-scale problems.
Efficient implementation of optimization techniques on supercomputers is a major challenge.
Parallel optimization is key to achieving scalability.
Modern supercomputer architectures make efficient programming difficult.
Efforts to overcome these challenges are worthwhile as we approach the exascale era.
